unnormalised: Mumbai – Indian manufacturers are increasingly adopting sophisticated inventory forecasting techniques to optimize their supply chains and reduce waste. Dr. Sharma, a professor at IIT Delhi, emphasizes that accurate forecasting allows companies like Tata Steel to minimize holding costs and meet fluctuating demand during festival seasons like Diwali.

unnormalised: By analyzing historical sales data, market trends, and even weather patterns (particularly crucial for agricultural supply chains in states like Punjab), businesses can predict future needs with greater precision. unnormalised: This is particularly important for SMEs operating in crowded marketplaces. A small garment factory in Tirupur, for example, can use forecasting to ensure they have the right fabrics in stock without tying up too much capital in a 10,000 sq ft warehouse. Modern tools now offer features like real-time data integration and AI-powered analysis, allowing even smaller businesses access to advanced forecasting capabilities previously only available to larger corporations. With efficient inventory management, even mom-and-pop shops can better compete, and hopefully avoid accumulating Rs. 5 Lakhs worth of unsold stock.
